Newsday Project

Long Island Children From Poor Neighborhoods Have Fewer Oppotunities

In Long Island, household income inequalities are closely related to unequal opportunities for children.

Ming Li

Published March 9, 2020

Children from different neighborhoods in Long Island face unequal oppotunity. A Newsday study has found that children from poor neighborhoods have fewer oppotunities.

The chart below shows that the household income is closely associated with the children's opportunity score (COS). The less household income of the neighborhood is, the fewer opportunities the children have.

The COS is part of a study called The Child Opportunity Index (COI) 2.0 by Brandeis University. The institution compares neighborhood opportunity for children across the United States based on census tracts.

The Long Island's household income data is based on the Data USA project by MIT and Deloitte.

Experts measure opportunities for children based on various indicators, including early childhood education and schools, safe housing, access to healthy food, parks and playgrounds and clean air etc.

The two maps below show the distributions of income and children's opportunity level in Long Island. Unfortunately, Long Island children from low income families are less likely to get opportunities to thrive.

Towns like Hempstead, Wyandanch or Riverhead not only have the lowest household income level, not also have the fewest oppotunities for children.

Methodology:

* About The Data:

Both the income data and COS are measured from the national levels.

* How Did I Make The Graphics:

I used Pandas to build and merge my dataframes. I used seaborn to plot the chart. The two maps were created in Qgis and then I threw everything in Adobe illustrator to make them prettier. I used sawhorse to build the whole page.

* Limitation About The Project:

The limitation is that the household income is perhaps one of the underlying indicators of the Children Oppotunity Index itself, so the findings may not be very suprising. In a way, it emphasizes the high correlation between economic status and children's opportunity level.

All the data and codes are on the project's Github page.
